title: Hydrogen Peroxide for Skin: Is It Safe to Use for Bleaching & Acne Treatments?

steps.title: No, doctors do not recommend using hydrogen peroxide on the skin.
steps.content: No, doctors do not recommend using hydrogen peroxide on the skin. In the past, hydrogen peroxide was commonly used to treat wounds, acne, and dark spots. [1] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source However, healthcare professionals no longer advise this because it can cause irritation and even damage the skin cells. [2] X Trustworthy Source U.S. National Capital Poison Center Independent poison control center providing resources to prevent poisonings and save lives Go to source Studies show that the potential side effects and risks of hydrogen peroxide outweigh the benefits. If you’re trying to lighten dark spots, use azelaic acid, glycolic acid, kojic acid, retinoids, or vitamin C instead. [3] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Side effects of hydrogen peroxide include skin burning and blistering.
steps.content: Side effects of hydrogen peroxide include skin burning and blistering. Generally, exposure to lower concentrations of hydrogen peroxide (3% or less) only causes mild irritation. Higher concentrations (10% or more) may lead to more serious side effects, which include: [4] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Allergic reactions (skin rash, itching, or hives) Swelling of the face, lips, or tongue Redness, burning, or blistering of the skin Eye pain or eyelid swelling Swelling skin ulcers Cracking or scarring of the skin

steps.title: Retinol
steps.content: Retinol According to skincare professional Alicia Ramos, “Retinol peels away the top layers of your skin, reducing the appearance of wrinkles, sun spots, and other pigmentation problems.” Retinol is available over-the-counter in gel , serum , or cream form. If you’re using it for the first time, cleanse your skin and let it dry completely, apply a thin layer of product, then follow up with a non-comedogenic moisturizer. [5] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Since retinol increases your skin’s sensitivity to the sun, only apply it at night, and be sure to wear sunscreen and protective clothing during the day. [6] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Common side effects of retinol include dryness, redness, irritation, itching, burning, or peeling or flaking of the skin. If you develop a painful or severe reaction, stop using it and contact your healthcare provider immediately. [7] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If you’ve never used retinol before, start with a pea-sized amount every other day and then use it daily after 3-4 weeks. Slowly incorporating the ingredient into your routine reduces the risk of side effects. [8] X Research source It may take several weeks to see an improvement in your skin. [9] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Glycolic acid
steps.content: Glycolic acid Glycolic acid is an alpha-hydroxy acid that works to smooth out the skin’s surface, refine pores, and improve discoloration, fine lines, and wrinkles. The acid can irritate your skin if you’ve never used it before, so start by applying it once or twice a week at night. [10] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Possible side effects of glycolic acid include reddening, stinging, or burning of the skin, as well as a pulling sensation. [11] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Glycolic acid is a common exfoliant in creams , serums , and masks . Look for a product with a concentration of 10% or less to minimize irritation, and follow the instructions of your specific product.

steps.title: Azelaic acid
steps.content: Azelaic acid Azelaic acid is a dicarboxylic acid that can reduce pigmentation and fade dark spots. [12] X Trustworthy Source DermNet NZ Online clinical resource website written and run by dermatologists providing evidence-based information about dermatology and skin health Go to source It’s a good option for people with sensitive skin or melasma, and it comes in cream, foam, and gel form. [13] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Apply a thin layer of cream to the affected area twice a day for at least 4 weeks. Potential side effects of azelaic acid include redness, scaling, itching, and burning of the skin. [14] X Trustworthy Source DermNet NZ Online clinical resource website written and run by dermatologists providing evidence-based information about dermatology and skin health Go to source

steps.title: Kojic acid
steps.content: Kojic acid According to licensed esthetician Kimberly Tan, “kojic acid is a powerhouse ingredient to brighten the skin.” Kojic acid prevents your skin from forming tyrosinase (an enzyme that helps create melanin), and studies show that it can reduce skin discoloration due to acne or sun damage. [15] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Look for serums , creams , or treatments that contain kojic acid. Kojic acid is usually well tolerated, but potential side effects include allergy or irritation. [16] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Vitamin C
steps.content: Vitamin C “Vitamin C serums work nicely to remove dark spots on the face,” according to board-certified dermatologist Aanand Geria, MD. When used topically, it can help even out skin tone by fading sun spots and reducing hyperpigmentation, but it usually takes about 3 months to see results. [17] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Choose a concentration that’s between 10-20%, and make sure it’s in a dark or tinted bottle. Apply vitamin C serum after cleansing your face (and after applying toner, if applicable). You can use it in the morning or at night, but it works in synergy with sunscreen.

steps.title: Hydroquinone
steps.content: Hydroquinone Hydroquinone is one of the most effective bleaching agents because it limits the skin’s production of melanin (the pigment responsible for skin color). While it is FDA-approved as a skin lightener, hydroquinone cream is only available by prescription. Talk to a doctor to see if it’s a good option for you, and follow the directions of your specific prescription. [18] X Trustworthy Source US Food and Drug Administration U.S. government agency responsible for promoting public health Go to source Make sure to wash your hands before and after using hydroquinone, and avoid excessive exposure to sunlight. Wear sunscreen (SPF 15 or higher) and protective clothing during the day. [19] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source The most common side effects of hydroquinone cream include mild itching, stinging, or redness of the skin. Serious side effects include rashes, facial swelling, and permanent skin discoloration. [20] X Trustworthy Source US Food and Drug Administration U.S. government agency responsible for promoting public health Go to source

steps.title: Hydrogen peroxide is water with an extra oxygen molecule.
steps.content: Hydrogen peroxide is water with an extra oxygen molecule. Since hydrogen peroxide is not as stable as water, it can release the extra oxygen molecule quickly and act as a bleach and disinfectant. [21] X Trustworthy Source U.S. National Capital Poison Center Independent poison control center providing resources to prevent poisonings and save lives Go to source Hydrogen peroxide is also a natural product of metabolism and plays a key role in managing oxidative stress in the body. [22] X Trustworthy Source Science Direct Online archive of peer-reviewed research on scientific, technical and medical topics Go to source

steps.title: Hydrogen peroxide is often used to disinfect surfaces and bleach hair.
steps.content: Hydrogen peroxide is often used to disinfect surfaces and bleach hair. For various industries, hydrogen peroxide is used as a bleach for paper and textiles, as a component of rocket fuels, and in the production of foam rubber and organic chemicals. [23] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source It’s also used to clean and disinfect surfaces, remove household stains, sanitize beauty tools and nails, and eliminate odors in dishwashers, sinks, toilets, garbage cans, and even litter boxes. [24] X Trustworthy Source U.S. National Capital Poison Center Independent poison control center providing resources to prevent poisonings and save lives Go to source In the past, hydrogen peroxide was commonly used to treat wounds, but it is no longer recommended because it can irritate or damage the cells needed for healing. [25] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source
